post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
OK, I had some serious trouble with that. After spending much more time wrestling with blender than pushing uvs, here we go:

http://members.westnet.com.au/GeoffGole ... PPED.blend

I suggest that you append the object from this file rather than just opening the .blend, since it's not likely you want all my wierd settings. (Putting user interface settings in the same file as mesh data is pretty stupid). Some stuff has been ripped out to make it easier for me to work with the mesh, but don't worry about that - just take a look at the seam placement and uv layout.

First thing to notice is that I don't just use long, continuous seams but also some short one-ended cuts. That allows lcsm to push uvs over those seams, which helps relax stretching. In a few spots that results in mapping that is not 1 to 1, but that shouldn't be a problem when you are using an existing world texture (it's a big nono if your uvs will be used for baking/lightmapping/painting though, keep that in mind). I pushed those spots to where I thought they would be difficult to see - without knowing what your lighting and mesh position is going to be in game it's a bit difficult to know, so you'll want to make that kind of decision for yourself.

Secondly, the unwrapping here is pin-free and based entirely on the cuts that I've made. The only change is that the resulting uvset has been rotated and scaled a bit. If you want to play with the seam layout, just add more and unwrap again.

Lastly, if I was modelling this myself I'd give some thought to other methods of getting rid of seams. There's a big nasty one down the middle of the bottom of this mesh, maybe I'd move that one to where I know there'll be shadows or model a boulder to go on top of it. You pointed out yourself that you could arrange for seams to go where you've blended in the dirt texture, that would be worth looking at. You could also add another crack on the other side of the bridge, as those are perfect spots to hide seams.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
thanks black dog and this is very interesting

firstly I didn`t know we could have seams that weren`t continuous edge loops. also great idea to hide the seams in cracks, I think I can do that quite easily from now on, and a few more beveled cracks will make the rocks look more interesting. and as you also suggested, covering them up with other models like boulders.

I might still use the odd pin, but I think your method will save me a lot of time in the future, as my uv maps were getting messed up a lot each time I added in more polys like the cracks, because the excessive pinning I was using was restricting the uv map from automatically shifting around while doing a lscm to compensate for the new polys uv`s.

so was this the first time you`ve used blender or was it just my .blend file that caused you problems? either way, I very much appreciate the time you spent on helping me with this

did you know we can use the file browser and deselect the "load ui" button at the bottom of the file browser?

this means that each blender user can retain their user prefs but load in other users project data (mesh, textures, materials etc) although some of the global prefs, like the paths blender looks for textures, are saved into the .b.blend file. although even that can be backed up or over written with global prefs for different projects we might be working on.

I do agree though it did seem stupid at first that blender saves some user prefs into the .blend project files, but I`ve got used to it.

which is the main modeling app you use?

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
I use blender extensively, but rather narrowly. In other words, I stick to a certain subset of features that I know very well and ignore the rest. Loading your .blend caused a few issues that I wasn't familiar with, so figuring them out took some time.

I did know that there was an option not to load the ui, just couldn't remember where the hell it was.

Quote:
I might still use the odd pin, but I think your method will save me a lot of time in the future, as my uv maps were getting messed up a lot each time I added in more polys like the cracks, because the excessive pinning I was using was restricting the uv map from automatically shifting around while doing a lscm to compensate for the new polys uv`s.


That's the main disadvantage of pinning. From what I can tell it's a more useful feature when doing things like unwrapping a character model, but I rarely use it on world geometry.

Patronising, no. Please never hesitate to tell me useful stuff. Maybe I already know it, maybe not.

Blender is certainly full of stuff to learn. The thing is, I have no need for most of it and I'm more interested in learning to make assets than learning Blender. My focus is entirely on modelling and unwrapping and as such dealing with the complexities of the rendering or materials systems just isn't appealing. Out of all the clever things that got added in 2.42, for instance, the only ones I have real use for are the uvlayout export (decent at last!) and the very useful merge to target vertex. Now they just need to make the knife tool snap to the grid.

While it's possible to have many seams on a model, I don't know that more is always better. The idea is simply to have the surface look as contiguous as possible without stretching, ideally using as few seams as possible. Learning how to do that effectively is really just a matter of unwrapping a few models and seeing what works.

Looking Good Ratty.

When it comes to UV-mapping in Blender I suggest you try the "Live UnWrap Transform" feature. This allows the skin to change as you move pinned faces making it very flexible to modify skins effectively. Although it wont move pinned faces so its best to have maybe 4 or 5 pins.

Depending on the size you could just leave the standard uv-map (Each quad/tris uses the entire texture) although if its not a repeating texture it will look silly..

Cant wait to see more.

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
Oops, should have kept an eye on this thread.

Quote:
I`m not familiar with "merge to target vertex" is it different from "merge verts to cursor" available in older versions of blender?


Yes. Before 2.42 this kind of merging was still possible by placing the cursor near a selected vertex, snapping the cursor to the selection, making a new selection and then merging that to the cursor. That was a big pain in the ass. Now there's "merge to first" and "merge to last" in the merge menu, which perform this function nicely. This is particularly useful for optimising low poly work.

Quote:
regarding the (edge cutting) knife tool, I always snap the resulting cuts manually to grid using the "shift+s" popup menu, but I first have to either zoom in the 3d window to a small enough grid, or keep another 3d window on screen with a small grid size, so the snapped verts are fine enough, other wise the model comes out looking to blocky. is this similar to how you use the knife tool?


Yes, I do roughly the same thing. The problem with this comes when you wish to make a clean, grid aligned slice through an object with off-grid vertices. Curves are a good example. When slicing those I always end up shuffling the new vertexes around to get them aligned, and that's not an effective way to work. Blender is entirely capable of making a clean grid-aligned cut, there's just no tool to do it at the moment.

I sometimes resort to booleans, but they are pretty bad. The modifier stack and the recent improvements do make them more useable, but the fact that meshes must be closed and need cleaning up afterwards just kills the ease of use.

So I'd like a knife tool that snaps to the grid.

Quote:
I`m pleased with how it looks in blender, but for some reason the vertex colors aren`t working on this model when loaded into blender.


The easiest way to verify that your vertex colours have exported is to load up the .ase file in a text editor and search for MESH_VERTCOL. Vertex colours are indexed in the .ase format in lines that look like this:

*MESH_VERTCOL 0 1.0000 1.0000 1.0000

If you are missing those, the exporter hasn't included vertex colours.

Quote:
here is my first attempt at uv mapping using the method black dog suggested.


Looks like you've got the idea. The crack running underneath looks like it'll hide seams very well. I would be a touch wary of adding features like that for the sole reason of hiding seams, as you want your model to be shaped naturally and believably as well as appearing seamless - but from that shot, it looks ok.

Quote:
but I wonder how you would unwrap the "horns" or saber type "teeth" that are in the original hell maps and my version of them, like in this image.


As kit said, I'd unwrap those with a single seam running up the back. I agree that having all three horns share the same uvspace is a good idea. It means you can save work by only modelling and unwrapping one and copying that geometry (perhaps with small changes), and it gives you the option to paint features into the texture such as highlighting the tip, or pushing the colour at the base further towards that of the material the horn will be growing from. You could go even further and try and paint out the seams, but depending on how the horn is used it may not be worth that effort.

understood and agreed they should fix this.

I haven`t yet used the boolean tools or the modifier stack, other then subsurf, armatures and wave modifiers for my music animation project.

one of the tasks I least enjoy when modeling my meshes is when I have two rows of verts I want to merge together along the seam, rather then all into the same vertex. I know if they are edge loops we can use the "3d view\mesh menu\scripts\bridge faces/edge loops" but with open ended rows it`s a pain to merge each pair of verts together.

some times I select each pair at a time and use the "s key" to drag them together, then use "w key\remove doubles" which although that whole process takes about the same time as using "w key\merge\at center" on each pair, I find the scaling method slightly more fun. what method do you use?

Quote:
The easiest way to verify that your vertex colours have exported is to load up the .ase file in a text editor and search for MESH_VERTCOL. Vertex colours are indexed in the .ase format in lines that look like this:

*MESH_VERTCOL 0 1.0000 1.0000 1.0000

If you are missing those, the exporter hasn't included vertex colours.

thanks and I`m still experimenting, but for some of the rocks I think cracks in them are a natural place to hide the seams, although I agree I can`t use that method on every model.

Quote:
As kit said, I'd unwrap those with a single seam running up the back. I agree that having all three horns share the same uvspace is a good idea. It means you can save work by only modeling and unwrapping one and copying that geometry (perhaps with small changes), and it gives you the option to paint features into the texture such as highlighting the tip, or pushing the colour at the base further towards that of the material the horn will be growing from. You could go even further and try and paint out the seams, but depending on how the horn is used it may not be worth that effort.

thanks and I`ll try a single seam up the back of the horns, I also thought about painting details onto the texture to fit within the exact shape of the horns rather then just use a wall like texture like they apparently did with the original d3 horns/saber teeth. and I`ve been vertex blending them into a rock or dirt texture which seems to work quite well, although the scale is a bit different since the rock models use a large scale on them then the rock base of the horns.

thanks for the suggestion, but I don`t think I`ll try painting out the seems, although I`ve done that before on some of the d3 character models for my personal mod. it is very time consuming especially when editing the local, height and specular textures as well as the diffuse (color) texture, not that these horns use all those material stages but it`s low priority, as plan to spend as much time on building as many models as possible, as well as all the sp game play events I have in mind

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
Quote:
one of the tasks I least enjoy when modeling my meshes is when I have two rows of verts I want to merge together along the seam, rather then all into the same vertex. I know if they are edge loops we can use the "3d view\mesh menu\scripts\bridge faces/edge loops" but with open ended rows it`s a pain to merge each pair of verts together.


Yes, that can be one of those tricky situations. If things are nicely aligned axially, sometimes you can get away with using the scaling trick constrained to an axis and do the whole lot at once. Also if you are doing radial work, sometimes you can avoid having to handle each vertex on a curve with smart use of scaling around the cursor, which can get you close enough that remove doubles will finish the job. Those are only special cases though, and anywhere they don't work I typically use either merge to target vertex or merge to center on individual pairs of verts.

Quote:
thanks for the suggestion, but I don`t think I`ll try painting out the seems


That comment was more to point out what advantages that kind of unwrapping can have than an actual suggestion. There's no point in doing unnecessary work, after all.

in the past I`ve concentrated more on adding as much detail as I can to everything I worked on, where by now because I know I have commitments to other projects so have less time available, I`m trying to improve my work flow by only adding in detail where the player is most likely to notice it, and then still keep it at a sensible level.

in fact when I first started building that rock bridge I didn`t intend the player to go up there, but I got carried away with adding detail to the top of the bridge, so have now concept designed a route which will take the player up there, hehe.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
just a quick update to show the newly remapped horn model, currently using one of the original d3 textures.



I did vertically stretch the uv`s after running lscm (or as it`s now called "unwrap" in blender 2.42a) so they could fit better the texture.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
sorry for lack of updates. the last few days I`ve been ill with a cold and previous to that I traveled up to derby for the bloodstock music festival with my girlfriend. although while there and on the trains and coaches I was able to do some concept designing, and review in my mind the construction methods I`ve been using on this map`s models to date.

my conclusion is the beveled cracks to hide the uv seams on the undersides of the rock bridge and some of the floating rocks was a waste of polys, especially as the player couldn`t really see them in game unless they noclipped into the air, to get close enough to the undersides of those rocks.

so when I got home from our long weekend, I merged the polys along either side of the uv seams, as well as redoing the seams and un wrapping for the first rocks I built.

what I have done though is added in some beveled edges to the cracks the player is likely to see, as they are a better use of the polys I think.

image shack seems slow today so I`ve only managed to ul one image so far, but will ul and post links to the finished rock bridge asap.

for now here`s a blender image of the latest version of the first rock, which the player spawns onto.



I also ran the blender script "uv/image editor\uv menu\texture baker" to output a version of the original pentastic1.tga texture, so in psp7 I could fade to black the inner edges where the decal sits on top of the rock`s cracks.

I`m especially pleased with how I got the decal`s mesh to follow the contours of those

Yes, that can be one of those tricky situations. If things are nicely aligned axially, sometimes you can get away with using the scaling trick constrained to an axis and do the whole lot at once.


thanks and I`ve used the scaling to an axis a few times in the past, but recently found it doesn`t work with most of the jagged edge loops my rocks have, which is a shame as it`s so fast and easy if the rows are axial to start with.

Quote:
Also if you are doing radial work, sometimes you can avoid having to handle each vertex on a curve with smart use of scaling around the cursor, which can get you close enough that remove doubles will finish the job.


interesting and thanks, I will keep it in mind

Quote:
Those are only special cases though, and anywhere they don't work I typically use either merge to target vertex or merge to center on individual pairs of verts.


understood and I wonder if they will ever give us a merge row type tool which works on these kind of organic shaped meshes?

Quote:
That comment was more to point out what advantages that kind of unwrapping can have than an actual suggestion. There's no point in doing unnecessary work, after all.


understood and agreed, and it was a cool idea

in the past I`ve concentrated more on adding as much detail as I can to everything I worked on, where by now because I know I have commitments to other projects so have less time available, I`m trying to improve my work flow by only adding in detail where the player is most likely to notice it, and then still keep it at a sensible level.

in fact when I first started building that rock bridge I didn`t intend the player to go up there, but I got carried away with adding detail to the top of the bridge, so have now concept designed a route which will take the player up there, hehe.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
just a quick update to show the newly remapped horn model, currently using one of the original d3 textures.



I did vertically stretch the uv`s after running lscm (or as it`s now called "unwrap" in blender 2.42a) so they could fit better the texture.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
sorry for lack of updates. the last few days I`ve been ill with a cold and previous to that I traveled up to derby for the bloodstock music festival with my girlfriend. although while there and on the trains and coaches I was able to do some concept designing, and review in my mind the construction methods I`ve been using on this map`s models to date.

my conclusion is the beveled cracks to hide the uv seams on the undersides of the rock bridge and some of the floating rocks was a waste of polys, especially as the player couldn`t really see them in game unless they noclipped into the air, to get close enough to the undersides of those rocks.

so when I got home from our long weekend, I merged the polys along either side of the uv seams, as well as redoing the seams and un wrapping for the first rocks I built.

what I have done though is added in some beveled edges to the cracks the player is likely to see, as they are a better use of the polys I think.

image shack seems slow today so I`ve only managed to ul one image so far, but will ul and post links to the finished rock bridge asap.

for now here`s a blender image of the latest version of the first rock, which the player spawns onto.



I also ran the blender script "uv/image editor\uv menu\texture baker" to output a version of the original pentastic1.tga texture, so in psp7 I could fade to black the inner edges where the decal sits on top of the rock`s cracks.

I`m especially pleased with how I got the decal`s mesh to follow the contours of those

post.author: Dewo
post.body: Hi Ratty, hi Kit! I'm here now .

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
for anyone interested in learning more about uv mapping and the lscm tool, here are two web page tutorials that I found helpful, the fist very basic, the 2nd advanced, but both have text and images.

The Basics of UV Mapping

Complex UV mapping tutorial

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: hi dewo, sorry I didn`t see your post before.

post.author: kat
post.body:
ratty redemption wrote:
...but I wonder how you would unwrap the "horns" or saber type "teeth" that are in the original hell maps and my version of them, like in this image....
Cylinder unwrap and place the seams on the outside of the model where they can't be easily seen by the player.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: thanks kat, although I`ve never used that before. and would it involve a seam going up say the back of the horn?

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
here is my first attempt at uv mapping using the method black dog suggested.



I`m pleased with how it looks in blender, but for some reason the vertex colors aren`t working on this model when loaded into blender.

in d3 the "r_showvertexcolor 1" shows a pure white model but in blender the vertex color has the top faces of the rock white fading to black for the sides and bottom of the rock.

could it be something to do with the seams that are preventing this from working?

edit: the pins are just to retain the size and rotation, but the distribution of uv`s is how the lscm unwrapped the model with it`s new seams.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
I got the vertex colors working again, it was my fault using my uv test material when exporting from blender which doesn`t have the "vcol paint" option enabled.

*ratty bangs head on desk*

but my normal d3 materials do and all seems to be working

post.author: kit89
post.body:
Yo Dewo.

Looking good Ratty, your getting the hang of this. For the horns, you could place a seam up the back of the horns. And if all the horns skin look the same, just place them on top of each other to reduce the texture size and your horns will look identical to each other.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
thanks kit89, and I`ve got a little more tweaking to the new rock I`ve been working on today but should have it finished tomorrow.

understood about the horns and yes they are all sharing the same uv map.

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
Oops, should have kept an eye on this thread.

Quote:
I`m not familiar with "merge to target vertex" is it different from "merge verts to cursor" available in older versions of blender?


Yes. Before 2.42 this kind of merging was still possible by placing the cursor near a selected vertex, snapping the cursor to the selection, making a new selection and then merging that to the cursor. That was a big pain in the ass. Now there's "merge to first" and "merge to last" in the merge menu, which perform this function nicely. This is particularly useful for optimising low poly work.

Quote:
regarding the (edge cutting) knife tool, I always snap the resulting cuts manually to grid using the "shift+s" popup menu, but I first have to either zoom in the 3d window to a small enough grid, or keep another 3d window on screen with a small grid size, so the snapped verts are fine enough, other wise the model comes out looking to blocky. is this similar to how you use the knife tool?


Yes, I do roughly the same thing. The problem with this comes when you wish to make a clean, grid aligned slice through an object with off-grid vertices. Curves are a good example. When slicing those I always end up shuffling the new vertexes around to get them aligned, and that's not an effective way to work. Blender is entirely capable of making a clean grid-aligned cut, there's just no tool to do it at the moment.

I sometimes resort to booleans, but they are pretty bad. The modifier stack and the recent improvements do make them more useable, but the fact that meshes must be closed and need cleaning up afterwards just kills the ease of use.

So I'd like a knife tool that snaps to the grid.

Quote:
I`m pleased with how it looks in blender, but for some reason the vertex colors aren`t working on this model when loaded into blender.


The easiest way to verify that your vertex colours have exported is to load up the .ase file in a text editor and search for MESH_VERTCOL. Vertex colours are indexed in the .ase format in lines that look like this:

*MESH_VERTCOL 0 1.0000 1.0000 1.0000

If you are missing those, the exporter hasn't included vertex colours.

Quote:
here is my first attempt at uv mapping using the method black dog suggested.


Looks like you've got the idea. The crack running underneath looks like it'll hide seams very well. I would be a touch wary of adding features like that for the sole reason of hiding seams, as you want your model to be shaped naturally and believably as well as appearing seamless - but from that shot, it looks ok.

Quote:
but I wonder how you would unwrap the "horns" or saber type "teeth" that are in the original hell maps and my version of them, like in this image.


As kit said, I'd unwrap those with a single seam running up the back. I agree that having all three horns share the same uvspace is a good idea. It means you can save work by only modelling and unwrapping one and copying that geometry (perhaps with small changes), and it gives you the option to paint features into the texture such as highlighting the tip, or pushing the colour at the base further towards that of the material the horn will be growing from. You could go even further and try and paint out the seams, but depending on how the horn is used it may not be worth that effort.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
black dog wrote:
Oops, should have kept an eye on this thread.

np, although I do intend to update this thread regularly when I`m working on the map and people seem interested to follow its progress.

Quote:
Yes. Before 2.42 this kind of merging was still possible by placing the cursor near a selected vertex, snapping the cursor to the selection, making a new selection and then merging that to the cursor. That was a big pain in the ass. Now there's "merge to first" and "merge to last" in the merge menu, which perform this function nicely. This is particularly useful for optimizing low poly work.

understood and agreed the old method is a pain to work with, so I`m now dl 2.42a because I often merge vertices and the new method sound much better

Quote:
Yes, I do roughly the same thing. The problem with this comes when you wish to make a clean, grid aligned slice through an object with off-grid vertices. Curves are a good example. When slicing those I always end up shuffling the new vertexes around to get them aligned, and that's not an effective way to work. Blender is entirely capable of making a clean grid-aligned cut, there's just no tool to do it at the moment.

understood and agreed they should fix this.

I haven`t yet used the boolean tools or the modifier stack, other then subsurf, armatures and wave modifiers for my music animation project.

one of the tasks I least enjoy when modeling my meshes is when I have two rows of verts I want to merge together along the seam, rather then all into the same vertex. I know if they are edge loops we can use the "3d view\mesh menu\scripts\bridge faces/edge loops" but with open ended rows it`s a pain to merge each pair of verts together.

some times I select each pair at a time and use the "s key" to drag them together, then use "w key\remove doubles" which although that whole process takes about the same time as using "w key\merge\at center" on each pair, I find the scaling method slightly more fun. what method do you use?

Quote:
The easiest way to verify that your vertex colours have exported is to load up the .ase file in a text editor and search for MESH_VERTCOL. Vertex colours are indexed in the .ase format in lines that look like this:

*MESH_VERTCOL 0 1.0000 1.0000 1.0000

If you are missing those, the exporter hasn't included vertex colours.

cool and thanks

Quote:
Looks like you've got the idea. The crack running underneath looks like it'll hide seams very well. I would be a touch wary of adding features like that for the sole reason of hiding seams, as you want your model to be shaped naturally and believably as well as appearing seamless - but from that shot, it looks ok.

thanks and I`m still experimenting, but for some of the rocks I think cracks in them are a natural place to hide the seams, although I agree I can`t use that method on every model.

Quote:
As kit said, I'd unwrap those with a single seam running up the back. I agree that having all three horns share the same uvspace is a good idea. It means you can save work by only modeling and unwrapping one and copying that geometry (perhaps with small changes), and it gives you the option to paint features into the texture such as highlighting the tip, or pushing the colour at the base further towards that of the material the horn will be growing from. You could go even further and try and paint out the seams, but depending on how the horn is used it may not be worth that effort.

thanks and I`ll try a single seam up the back of the horns, I also thought about painting details onto the texture to fit within the exact shape of the horns rather then just use a wall like texture like they apparently did with the original d3 horns/saber teeth. and I`ve been vertex blending them into a rock or dirt texture which seems to work quite well, although the scale is a bit different since the rock models use a large scale on them then the rock base of the horns.

thanks for the suggestion, but I don`t think I`ll try painting out the seems, although I`ve done that before on some of the d3 character models for my personal mod. it is very time consuming especially when editing the local, height and specular textures as well as the diffuse (color) texture, not that these horns use all those material stages but it`s low priority, as plan to spend as much time on building as many models as possible, as well as all the sp game play events I have in mind

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
Quote:
one of the tasks I least enjoy when modeling my meshes is when I have two rows of verts I want to merge together along the seam, rather then all into the same vertex. I know if they are edge loops we can use the "3d view\mesh menu\scripts\bridge faces/edge loops" but with open ended rows it`s a pain to merge each pair of verts together.


Yes, that can be one of those tricky situations. If things are nicely aligned axially, sometimes you can get away with using the scaling trick constrained to an axis and do the whole lot at once. Also if you are doing radial work, sometimes you can avoid having to handle each vertex on a curve with smart use of scaling around the cursor, which can get you close enough that remove doubles will finish the job. Those are only special cases though, and anywhere they don't work I typically use either merge to target vertex or merge to center on individual pairs of verts.

Quote:
thanks for the suggestion, but I don`t think I`ll try painting out the seems


That comment was more to point out what advantages that kind of unwrapping can have than an actual suggestion. There's no point in doing unnecessary work, after all.

sorry for lack of updates. the last few days I`ve been ill with a cold and previous to that I traveled up to derby for the bloodstock music festival with my girlfriend. although while there and on the trains and coaches I was able to do some concept designing, and review in my mind the construction methods I`ve been using on this map`s models to date.

my conclusion is the beveled cracks to hide the uv seams on the undersides of the rock bridge and some of the floating rocks was a waste of polys, especially as the player couldn`t really see them in game unless they noclipped into the air, to get close enough to the undersides of those rocks.

so when I got home from our long weekend, I merged the polys along either side of the uv seams, as well as redoing the seams and un wrapping for the first rocks I built.

what I have done though is added in some beveled edges to the cracks the player is likely to see, as they are a better use of the polys I think.

image shack seems slow today so I`ve only

post.author: Dewo
post.body: Hi Ratty, hi Kit! I'm here now .

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
for anyone interested in learning more about uv mapping and the lscm tool, here are two web page tutorials that I found helpful, the fist very basic, the 2nd advanced, but both have text and images.

The Basics of UV Mapping

Complex UV mapping tutorial

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: hi dewo, sorry I didn`t see your post before.

post.author: kat
post.body:
ratty redemption wrote:
...but I wonder how you would unwrap the "horns" or saber type "teeth" that are in the original hell maps and my version of them, like in this image....
Cylinder unwrap and place the seams on the outside of the model where they can't be easily seen by the player.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: thanks kat, although I`ve never used that before. and would it involve a seam going up say the back of the horn?

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
here is my first attempt at uv mapping using the method black dog suggested.



I`m pleased with how it looks in blender, but for some reason the vertex colors aren`t working on this model when loaded into blender.

in d3 the "r_showvertexcolor 1" shows a pure white model but in blender the vertex color has the top faces of the rock white fading to black for the sides and bottom of the rock.

could it be something to do with the seams that are preventing this from working?

edit: the pins are just to retain the size and rotation, but the distribution of uv`s is how the lscm unwrapped the model with it`s new seams.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
I got the vertex colors working again, it was my fault using my uv test material when exporting from blender which doesn`t have the "vcol paint" option enabled.

*ratty bangs head on desk*

but my normal d3 materials do and all seems to be working

post.author: kit89
post.body:
Yo Dewo.

Looking good Ratty, your getting the hang of this. For the horns, you could place a seam up the back of the horns. And if all the horns skin look the same, just place them on top of each other to reduce the texture size and your horns will look identical to each other.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
thanks kit89, and I`ve got a little more tweaking to the new rock I`ve been working on today but should have it finished tomorrow.

understood about the horns and yes they are all sharing the same uv map.

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
Oops, should have kept an eye on this thread.

Quote:
I`m not familiar with "merge to target vertex" is it different from "merge verts to cursor" available in older versions of blender?


Yes. Before 2.42 this kind of merging was still possible by placing the cursor near a selected vertex, snapping the cursor to the selection, making a new selection and then merging that to the cursor. That was a big pain in the ass. Now there's "merge to first" and "merge to last" in the merge menu, which perform this function nicely. This is particularly useful for optimising low poly work.

Quote:
regarding the (edge cutting) knife tool, I always snap the resulting cuts manually to grid using the "shift+s" popup menu, but I first have to either zoom in the 3d window to a small enough grid, or keep another 3d window on screen with a small grid size, so the snapped verts are fine enough, other wise the model comes out looking to blocky. is this similar to how you use the knife tool?


Yes, I do roughly the same thing. The problem with this comes when you wish to make a clean, grid aligned slice through an object with off-grid vertices. Curves are a good example. When slicing those I always end up shuffling the new vertexes around to get them aligned, and that's not an effective way to work. Blender is entirely capable of making a clean grid-aligned cut, there's just no tool to do it at the moment.

I sometimes resort to booleans, but they are pretty bad. The modifier stack and the recent improvements do make them more useable, but the fact that meshes must be closed and need cleaning up afterwards just kills the ease of use.

So I'd like a knife tool that snaps to the grid.

Quote:
I`m pleased with how it looks in blender, but for some reason the vertex colors aren`t working on this model when loaded into blender.


The easiest way to verify that your vertex colours have exported is to load up the .ase file in a text editor and search for MESH_VERTCOL. Vertex colours are indexed in the .ase format in lines that look like this:

*MESH_VERTCOL 0 1.0000 1.0000 1.0000

If you are missing those, the exporter hasn't included vertex colours.

Quote:
here is my first attempt at uv mapping using the method black dog suggested.


Looks like you've got the idea. The crack running underneath looks like it'll hide seams very well. I would be a touch wary of adding features like that for the sole reason of hiding seams, as you want your model to be shaped naturally and believably as well as appearing seamless - but from that shot, it looks ok.

Quote:
but I wonder how you would unwrap the "horns" or saber type "teeth" that are in the original hell maps and my version of them, like in this image.


As kit said, I'd unwrap those with a single seam running up the back. I agree that having all three horns share the same uvspace is a good idea. It means you can save work by only modelling and unwrapping one and copying that geometry (perhaps with small changes), and it gives you the option to paint features into the texture such as highlighting the tip, or pushing the colour at the base further towards that of the material the horn will be growing from. You could go even further and try and paint out the seams, but depending on how the horn is used it may not be worth that effort.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
black dog wrote:
Oops, should have kept an eye on this thread.

np, although I do intend to update this thread regularly when I`m working on the map and people seem interested to follow its progress.

Quote:
Yes. Before 2.42 this kind of merging was still possible by placing the cursor near a selected vertex, snapping the cursor to the selection, making a new selection and then merging that to the cursor. That was a big pain in the ass. Now there's "merge to first" and "merge to last" in the merge menu, which perform this function nicely. This is particularly useful for optimizing low poly work.

understood and agreed the old method is a pain to work with, so I`m now dl 2.42a because I often merge vertices and the new method sound much better

Quote:
Yes, I do roughly the same thing. The problem with this comes when you wish to make a clean, grid aligned slice through an object with off-grid vertices. Curves are a good example. When slicing those I always end up shuffling the new vertexes around to get them aligned, and that's not an effective way to work. Blender is entirely capable of making a clean grid-aligned cut, there's just no tool to do it at the moment.

understood and agreed they should fix this.

I haven`t yet used the boolean tools or the modifier stack, other then subsurf, armatures and wave modifiers for my music animation project.

one of the tasks I least enjoy when modeling my meshes is when I have two rows of verts I want to merge together along the seam, rather then all into the same vertex. I know if they are edge loops we can use the "3d view\mesh menu\scripts\bridge faces/edge loops" but with open ended rows it`s a pain to merge each pair of verts together.

some times I select each pair at a time and use the "s key" to drag them together, then use "w key\remove doubles" which although that whole process takes about the same time as using "w key\merge\at center" on each pair, I find the scaling method slightly more fun. what method do you use?

Quote:
The easiest way to verify that your vertex colours have exported is to load up the .ase file in a text editor and search for MESH_VERTCOL. Vertex colours are indexed in the .ase format in lines that look like this:

*MESH_VERTCOL 0 1.0000 1.0000 1.0000

If you are missing those, the exporter hasn't included vertex colours.

cool and thanks

Quote:
Looks like you've got the idea. The crack running underneath looks like it'll hide seams very well. I would be a touch wary of adding features like that for the sole reason of hiding seams, as you want your model to be shaped naturally and believably as well as appearing seamless - but from that shot, it looks ok.

thanks and I`m still experimenting, but for some of the rocks I think cracks in them are a natural place to hide the seams, although I agree I can`t use that method on every model.

Quote:
As kit said, I'd unwrap those with a single seam running up the back. I agree that having all three horns share the same uvspace is a good idea. It means you can save work by only modeling and unwrapping one and copying that geometry (perhaps with small changes), and it gives you the option to paint features into the texture such as highlighting the tip, or pushing the colour at the base further towards that of the material the horn will be growing from. You could go even further and try and paint out the seams, but depending on how the horn is used it may not be worth that effort.

thanks and I`ll try a single seam up the back of the horns, I also thought about painting details onto the texture to fit within the exact shape of the horns rather then just use a wall like texture like they apparently did with the original d3 horns/saber teeth. and I`ve been vertex blending them into a rock or dirt texture which seems to work quite well, although the scale is a bit different since the rock models use a large scale on them then the rock base of the horns.

thanks for the suggestion, but I don`t think I`ll try painting out the seems, although I`ve done that before on some of the d3 character models for my personal mod. it is very time consuming especially when editing the local, height and specular textures as well as the diffuse (color) texture, not that these horns use all those material stages but it`s low priority, as plan to spend as much time on building as many models as possible, as well as all the sp game play events I have in mind

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
Quote:
one of the tasks I least enjoy when modeling my meshes is when I have two rows of verts I want to merge together along the seam, rather then all into the same vertex. I know if they are edge loops we can use the "3d view\mesh menu\scripts\bridge faces/edge loops" but with open ended rows it`s a pain to merge each pair of verts together.


Yes, that can be one of those tricky situations. If things are nicely aligned axially, sometimes you can get away with using the scaling trick constrained to an axis and do the whole lot at once. Also if you are doing radial work, sometimes you can avoid having to handle each vertex on a curve with smart use of scaling around the cursor, which can get you close enough that remove doubles will finish the job. Those are only special cases though, and anywhere they don't work I typically use either merge to target vertex or merge to center on individual pairs of verts.

Quote:
thanks for the suggestion, but I don`t think I`ll try painting out the seems


That comment was more to point out what advantages that kind of unwrapping can have than an actual suggestion. There's no point in doing unnecessary work, after all.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
black dog wrote:
Yes, that can be one of those tricky situations. If things are nicely aligned axially, sometimes you can get away with using the scaling trick constrained to an axis and do the whole lot at once.


thanks and I`ve used the scaling to an axis a few times in the past, but recently found it doesn`t work with most of the jagged edge loops my rocks have, which is a shame as it`s so fast and easy if the rows are axial to start with.

Quote:
Also if you are doing radial work, sometimes you can avoid having to handle each vertex on a curve with smart use of scaling around the cursor, which can get you close enough that remove doubles will finish the job.


interesting and thanks, I will keep it in mind

Quote:
Those are only special cases though, and anywhere they don't work I typically use either merge to target vertex or merge to center on individual pairs of verts.


understood and I wonder if they will ever give us a merge row type tool which works on these kind of organic shaped meshes?

Quote:
That comment was more to point out what advantages that kind of unwrapping can have than an actual suggestion. There's no point in doing unnecessary work, after all.


understood and agreed, and it was a cool idea

in the past I`ve concentrated more on adding as much detail as I can to everything I worked on, where by now because I know I have commitments to other projects so have less time available, I`m trying to improve my work flow by only adding in detail where the player is most likely to notice it, and then still keep it at a sensible level.

in fact when I first started building that rock bridge I didn`t intend the player to go up there, but I got carried away with adding detail to the top of the bridge, so have now concept designed a route which will take the player up there, hehe.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
just a quick update to show the newly remapped horn model, currently using one of the original d3 textures.



I did vertically stretch the uv`s after running lscm (or as it`s now called "unwrap" in blender 2.42a) so they could fit better the texture.

edit: the pins are just to retain the size and rotation, but the distribution of uv`s is how the lscm unwrapped the model with it`s new seams.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
I got the vertex colors working again, it was my fault using my uv test material when exporting from blender which doesn`t have the "vcol paint" option enabled.

*ratty bangs head on desk*

but my normal d3 materials do and all seems to be working

post.author: kit89
post.body:
Yo Dewo.

Looking good Ratty, your getting the hang of this. For the horns, you could place a seam up the back of the horns. And if all the horns skin look the same, just place them on top of each other to reduce the texture size and your horns will look identical to each other.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
thanks kit89, and I`ve got a little more tweaking to the new rock I`ve been working on today but should have it finished tomorrow.

understood about the horns and yes they are all sharing the same uv map.

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
Oops, should have kept an eye on this thread.

Quote:
I`m not familiar with "merge to target vertex" is it different from "merge verts to cursor" available in older versions of blender?


Yes. Before 2.42 this kind of merging was still possible by placing the cursor near a selected vertex, snapping the cursor to the selection, making a new selection and then merging that to the cursor. That was a big pain in the ass. Now there's "merge to first" and "merge to last" in the merge menu, which perform this function nicely. This is particularly useful for optimising low poly work.

Quote:
regarding the (edge cutting) knife tool, I always snap the resulting cuts manually to grid using the "shift+s" popup menu, but I first have to either zoom in the 3d window to a small enough grid, or keep another 3d window on screen with a small grid size, so the snapped verts are fine enough, other wise the model comes out looking to blocky. is this similar to how you use the knife tool?


Yes, I do roughly the same thing. The problem with this comes when you wish to make a clean, grid aligned slice through an object with off-grid vertices. Curves are a good example. When slicing those I always end up shuffling the new vertexes around to get them aligned, and that's not an effective way to work. Blender is entirely capable of making a clean grid-aligned cut, there's just no tool to do it at the moment.

I sometimes resort to booleans, but they are pretty bad. The modifier stack and the recent improvements do make them more useable, but the fact that meshes must be closed and need cleaning up afterwards just kills the ease of use.

So I'd like a knife tool that snaps to the grid.

Quote:
I`m pleased with how it looks in blender, but for some reason the vertex colors aren`t working on this model when loaded into blender.


The easiest way to verify that your vertex colours have exported is to load up the .ase file in a text editor and search for MESH_VERTCOL. Vertex colours are indexed in the .ase format in lines that look like this:

*MESH_VERTCOL 0 1.0000 1.0000 1.0000

If you are missing those, the exporter hasn't included vertex colours.

Quote:
here is my first attempt at uv mapping using the method black dog suggested.


Looks like you've got the idea. The crack running underneath looks like it'll hide seams very well. I would be a touch wary of adding features like that for the sole reason of hiding seams, as you want your model to be shaped naturally and believably as well as appearing seamless - but from that shot, it looks ok.

Quote:
but I wonder how you would unwrap the "horns" or saber type "teeth" that are in the original hell maps and my version of them, like in this image.


As kit said, I'd unwrap those with a single seam running up the back. I agree that having all three horns share the same uvspace is a good idea. It means you can save work by only modelling and unwrapping one and copying that geometry (perhaps with small changes), and it gives you the option to paint features into the texture such as highlighting the tip, or pushing the colour at the base further towards that of the material the horn will be growing from. You could go even further and try and paint out the seams, but depending on how the horn is used it may not be worth that effort.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
black dog wrote:
Oops, should have kept an eye on this thread.

np, although I do intend to update this thread regularly when I`m working on the map and people seem interested to follow its progress.

Quote:
Yes. Before 2.42 this kind of merging was still possible by placing the cursor near a selected vertex, snapping the cursor to the selection, making a new selection and then merging that to the cursor. That was a big pain in the ass. Now there's "merge to first" and "merge to last" in the merge menu, which perform this function nicely. This is particularly useful for optimizing low poly work.

understood and agreed the old method is a pain to work with, so I`m now dl 2.42a because I often merge vertices and the new method sound much better

Quote:
Yes, I do roughly the same thing. The problem with this comes when you wish to make a clean, grid aligned slice through an object with off-grid vertices. Curves are a good example. When slicing those I always end up shuffling the new vertexes around to get them aligned, and that's not an effective way to work. Blender is entirely capable of making a clean grid-aligned cut, there's just no tool to do it at the moment.

understood and agreed they should fix this.

I haven`t yet used the boolean tools or the modifier stack, other then subsurf, armatures and wave modifiers for my music animation project.

one of the tasks I least enjoy when modeling my meshes is when I have two rows of verts I want to merge together along the seam, rather then all into the same vertex. I know if they are edge loops we can use the "3d view\mesh menu\scripts\bridge faces/edge loops" but with open ended rows it`s a pain to merge each pair of verts together.

some times I select each pair at a time and use the "s key" to drag them together, then use "w key\remove doubles" which although that whole process takes about the same time as using "w key\merge\at center" on each pair, I find the scaling method slightly more fun. what method do you use?

Quote:
The easiest way to verify that your vertex colours have exported is to load up the .ase file in a text editor and search for MESH_VERTCOL. Vertex colours are indexed in the .ase format in lines that look like this:

*MESH_VERTCOL 0 1.0000 1.0000 1.0000

If you are missing those, the exporter hasn't included vertex colours.

cool and thanks

Quote:
Looks like you've got the idea. The crack running underneath looks like it'll hide seams very well. I would be a touch wary of adding features like that for the sole reason of hiding seams, as you want your model to be shaped naturally and believably as well as appearing seamless - but from that shot, it looks ok.

thanks and I`m still experimenting, but for some of the rocks I think cracks in them are a natural place to hide the seams, although I agree I can`t use that method on every model.

Quote:
As kit said, I'd unwrap those with a single seam running up the back. I agree that having all three horns share the same uvspace is a good idea. It means you can save work by only modeling and unwrapping one and copying that geometry (perhaps with small changes), and it gives you the option to paint features into the texture such as highlighting the tip, or pushing the colour at the base further towards that of the material the horn will be growing from. You could go even further and try and paint out the seams, but depending on how the horn is used it may not be worth that effort.

thanks and I`ll try a single seam up the back of the horns, I also thought about painting details onto the texture to fit within the exact shape of the horns rather then just use a wall like texture like they apparently did with the original d3 horns/saber teeth. and I`ve been vertex blending them into a rock or dirt texture which seems to work quite well, although the scale is a bit different since the rock models use a large scale on them then the rock base of the horns.

thanks for the suggestion, but I don`t think I`ll try painting out the seems, although I`ve done that before on some of the d3 character models for my personal mod. it is very time consuming especially when editing the local, height and specular textures as well as the diffuse (color) texture, not that these horns use all those material stages but it`s low priority, as plan to spend as much time on building as many models as possible, as well as all the sp game play events I have in mind

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
Quote:
one of the tasks I least enjoy when modeling my meshes is when I have two rows of verts I want to merge together along the seam, rather then all into the same vertex. I know if they are edge loops we can use the "3d view\mesh menu\scripts\bridge faces/edge loops" but with open ended rows it`s a pain to merge each pair of verts together.


Yes, that can be one of those tricky situations. If things are nicely aligned axially, sometimes you can get away with using the scaling trick constrained to an axis and do the whole lot at once. Also if you are doing radial work, sometimes you can avoid having to handle each vertex on a curve with smart use of scaling around the cursor, which can get you close enough that remove doubles will finish the job. Those are only special cases though, and anywhere they don't work I typically use either merge to target vertex or merge to center on individual pairs of verts.

Quote:
thanks for the suggestion, but I don`t think I`ll try painting out the seems


That comment was more to point out what advantages that kind of unwrapping can have than an actual suggestion. There's no point in doing unnecessary work, after all.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
black dog wrote:
Yes, that can be one of those tricky situations. If things are nicely aligned axially, sometimes you can get away with using the scaling trick constrained to an axis and do the whole lot at once.


thanks and I`ve used the scaling to an axis a few times in the past, but recently found it doesn`t work with most of the jagged edge loops my rocks have, which is a shame as it`s so fast and easy if the rows are axial to start with.

Quote:
Also if you are doing radial work, sometimes you can avoid having to handle each vertex on a curve with smart use of scaling around the cursor, which can get you close enough that remove doubles will finish the job.


interesting and thanks, I will keep it in mind

Quote:
Those are only special cases though, and anywhere they don't work I typically use either merge to target vertex or merge to center on individual pairs of verts.


understood and I wonder if they will ever give us a merge row type tool which works on these kind of organic shaped meshes?

Quote:
That comment was more to point out what advantages that kind of unwrapping can have than an actual suggestion. There's no point in doing unnecessary work, after all.


understood and agreed, and it was a cool idea

in the past I`ve concentrated more on adding as much detail as I can to everything I worked on, where by now because I know I have commitments to other projects so have less time available, I`m trying to improve my work flow by only adding in detail where the player is most likely to notice it, and then still keep it at a sensible level.

in fact when I first started building that rock bridge I didn`t intend the player to go up there, but I got carried away with adding detail to the top of the bridge, so have now concept designed a route which will take the player up there, hehe.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
just a quick update to show the newly remapped horn model, currently using one of the original d3 textures.



I did vertically stretch the uv`s after running lscm (or as it`s now called "unwrap" in blender 2.42a) so they could fit better the texture.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
sorry for lack of updates. the last few days I`ve been ill with a cold and previous to that I traveled up to derby for the bloodstock music festival with my girlfriend. although while there and on the trains and coaches I was able to do some concept designing, and review in my mind the construction methods I`ve been using on this map`s models to date.

my conclusion is the beveled cracks to hide the uv seams on the undersides of the rock bridge and some of the floating rocks was a waste of polys, especially as the player couldn`t really see them in game unless they noclipped into the air, to get close enough to the undersides of those rocks.

so when I got home from our long weekend, I merged the polys along either side of the uv seams, as well as redoing the seams and un wrapping for the first rocks I built.

what I have done though is added in some beveled edges to the cracks the player is likely to see, as they are a better use of the polys I think.

image shack seems slow today so I`ve only managed to ul one image so far, but will ul and post links to the finished rock bridge asap.

for now here`s a blender image of the latest version of the first rock, which the player spawns onto.



I also ran the blender script "uv/image editor\uv menu\texture baker" to output a version of the original pentastic1.tga texture, so in psp7 I could fade to black the inner edges where the decal sits on top of the rock`s cracks.

I`m especially pleased with how I got the decal`s mesh to follow the contours of thos

post.body: Hi Ratty, hi Kit! I'm here now .

The Basics of UV Mapping

Complex UV mapping tutorial

regarding the (edge cutting) knife tool, I always snap the resulting cuts manually to grid using the "shift+s" popup menu, but I first have to either zoom in the 3d window to a small enough grid, or keep another 3d window on screen with a small grid size, so the snapped verts are fine enough, other wise the model comes out looking to blocky. is this similar to how you use the knife tool?


Yes, I do roughly the same thing. The problem with this comes when you wish to make a clean, grid aligned slice through an object with off-grid vertices. Curves are a good example. When slicing those I always end up shuffling the new vertexes around to get them aligned, and that's not an effective way to work. Blender is entirely capable of making a clean grid-aligned cut, there's just no tool to do it at the moment.

I sometimes resort to booleans, but they are pretty bad. The modifier stack and the recent improvements do make them more useable, but the fact that meshes must be closed and need cleaning up afterwards just kills the ease of use.

So I'd like a knife tool that snaps to the grid.

Quote:
I`m pleased with how it looks in blender, but for some reason the vertex colors aren`t working on this model when loaded into blender.


The easiest way to verify that your vertex colours have exported is to load up the .ase file in a text editor and search for MESH_VERTCOL. Vertex colours are indexed in the .ase format in lines that look like this:

*MESH_VERTCOL 0 1.0000 1.0000 1.0000

If you are missing those, the exporter hasn't included vertex colours.

Quote:
here is my first attempt at uv mapping using the method black dog suggested.


Looks like you've got the idea. The crack running underneath looks like it'll hide seams very well. I would be a touch wary of adding features like that for the sole reason of hiding seams, as you want your model to be shaped naturally and believably as well as appearing seamless - but from that shot, it looks ok.

Quote:
but I wonder how you would unwrap the "horns" or saber type "teeth" that are in the original hell maps and my version of them, like in this image.


As kit said, I'd unwrap those with a single seam running up the back. I agree that having all three horns share the same uvspace is a good idea. It means you can save work by only modelling and unwrapping one and copying that geometry (perhaps with small changes), and it gives you the option to paint features into the texture such as highlighting the tip, or pushing the colour at the base further towards that of the material the horn will be growing from. You could go even further and try and paint out the seams, but depending on how the horn is used it may not be worth that effort.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
black dog wrote:
Oops, should have kept an eye on this thread.

np, although I do intend to update this thread regularly when I`m working on the map and people seem interested to follow its progress.

Quote:
Yes. Before 2.42 this kind of merging was still possible by placing the cursor near a selected vertex, snapping the cursor to the selection, making a new selection and then merging that to the cursor. That was a big pain in the ass. Now there's "merge to first" and "merge to last" in the merge menu, which perform this function nicely. This is particularly useful for optimizing low poly work.

understood and agreed the old method is a pain to work with, so I`m now dl 2.42a because I often merge vertices and the new method sound much better

Quote:
Yes, I do roughly the same thing. The problem with this comes when you wish to make a clean, grid aligned slice through an object with off-grid vertices. Curves are a good example. When slicing those I always end up shuffling the new vertexes around to get them aligned, and that's not an effective way to work. Blender is entirely capable of making a clean grid-aligned cut, there's just no tool to do it at the moment.

understood and agreed they should fix this.

I haven`t yet used the boolean tools or the modifier stack, other then subsurf, armatures and wave modifiers for my music animation project.

one of the tasks I least enjoy when modeling my meshes is when I have two rows of verts I want to merge together along the seam, rather then all into the same vertex. I know if they are edge loops we can use the "3d view\mesh menu\scripts\bridge faces/edge loops" but with open ended rows it`s a pain to merge each pair of verts together.

some times I select each pair at a time and use the "s key" to drag them together, then use "w key\remove doubles" which although that whole process takes about the same time as using "w key\merge\at center" on each pair, I find the scaling method slightly more fun. what method do you use?

Quote:
The easiest way to verify that your vertex colours have exported is to load up the .ase file in a text editor and search for MESH_VERTCOL. Vertex colours are indexed in the .ase format in lines that look like this:

*MESH_VERTCOL 0 1.0000 1.0000 1.0000

If you are missing those, the exporter hasn't included vertex colours.

cool and thanks

Quote:
Looks like you've got the idea. The crack running underneath looks like it'll hide seams very well. I would be a touch wary of adding features like that for the sole reason of hiding seams, as you want your model to be shaped naturally and believably as well as appearing seamless - but from that shot, it looks ok.

thanks and I`m still experimenting, but for some of the rocks I think cracks in them are a natural place to hide the seams, although I agree I can`t use that method on every model.

Quote:
As kit said, I'd unwrap those with a single seam running up the back. I agree that having all three horns share the same uvspace is a good idea. It means you can save work by only modeling and unwrapping one and copying that geometry (perhaps with small changes), and it gives you the option to paint features into the texture such as highlighting the tip, or pushing the colour at the base further towards that of the material the horn will be growing from. You could go even further and try and paint out the seams, but depending on how the horn is used it may not be worth that effort.

thanks and I`ll try a single seam up the back of the horns, I also thought about painting details onto the texture to fit within the exact shape of the horns rather then just use a wall like texture like they apparently did with the original d3 horns/saber teeth. and I`ve been vertex blending them into a rock or dirt texture which seems to work quite well, although the scale is a bit different since the rock models use a large scale on them then the rock base of the horns.

thanks for the suggestion, but I don`t think I`ll try painting out the seems, although I`ve done that before on some of the d3 character models for my personal mod. it is very time consuming especially when editing the local, height and specular textures as well as the diffuse (color) texture, not that these horns use all those material stages but it`s low priority, as plan to spend as much time on building as many models as possible, as well as all the sp game play events I have in mind

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
Quote:
one of the tasks I least enjoy when modeling my meshes is when I have two rows of verts I want to merge together along the seam, rather then all into the same vertex. I know if they are edge loops we can use the "3d view\mesh menu\scripts\bridge faces/edge loops" but with open ended rows it`s a pain to merge each pair of verts together.


Yes, that can be one of those tricky situations. If things are nicely aligned axially, sometimes you can get away with using the scaling trick constrained to an axis and do the whole lot at once. Also if you are doing radial work, sometimes you can avoid having to handle each vertex on a curve with smart use of scaling around the cursor, which can get you close enough that remove doubles will finish the job. Those are only special cases though, and anywhere they don't work I typically use either merge to target vertex or merge to center on individual pairs of verts.

Quote:
thanks for the suggestion, but I don`t think I`ll try painting out the seems


That comment was more to point out what advantages that kind of unwrapping can have than an actual suggestion. There's no point in doing unnecessary work, after all.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
black dog wrote:
Yes, that can be one of those tricky situations. If things are nicely aligned axially, sometimes you can get away with using the scaling trick constrained to an axis and do the whole lot at once.


thanks and I`ve used the scaling to an axis a few times in the past, but recently found it doesn`t work with most of the jagged edge loops my rocks have, which is a shame as it`s so fast and easy if the rows are axial to start with.

Quote:
Also if you are doing radial work, sometimes you can avoid having to handle each vertex on a curve with smart use of scaling around the cursor, which can get you close enough that remove doubles will finish the job.


interesting and thanks, I will keep it in mind

Quote:
Those are only special cases though, and anywhere they don't work I typically use either merge to target vertex or merge to center on individual pairs of verts.


understood and I wonder if they will ever give us a merge row type tool which works on these kind of organic shaped meshes?

Quote:
That comment was more to point out what advantages that kind of unwrapping can have than an actual suggestion. There's no point in doing unnecessary work, after all.


understood and agreed, and it was a cool idea

in the past I`ve concentrated more on adding as much detail as I can to everything I worked on, where by now because I know I have commitments to other projects so have less time available, I`m trying to improve my work flow by only adding in detail where the player is most likely to notice it, and then still keep it at a sensible level.

in fact when I first started building that rock bridge I didn`t intend the player to go up there, but I got carried away with adding detail to the top of the bridge, so have now concept designed a route which will take the player up there, hehe.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
just a quick update to show the newly remapped horn model, currently using one of the original d3 textures.



I did vertically stretch the uv`s after running lscm (or as it`s now called "unwrap" in blender 2.42a) so they could fit better the texture.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
sorry for lack of updates. the last few days I`ve been ill with a cold and previous to that I traveled up to derby for the bloodstock music festival with my girlfriend. although while there and on the trains and coaches I was able to do some concept designing, and review in my mind the construction methods I`ve been using on this map`s models to date.

my conclusion is the beveled cracks to hide the uv seams on the undersides of the rock bridge and some of the floating rocks was a waste of polys, especially as the player couldn`t really see them in game unless they noclipped into the air, to get close enough to the undersides of those rocks.

so when I got home from our long weekend, I merged the polys along either side of the uv seams, as well as redoing the seams and un wrapping for the first rocks I built.

what I have done though is added in some beveled edges to the cracks the player is likely to see, as they are a better use of the polys I think.

image shack seems slow today so I`ve only managed to ul one image so far, but will ul and post links to the finished rock bridge asap.

for now here`s a blender image of the latest version of the first rock, which the player spawns onto.



I also ran the blender script "uv/image editor\uv menu\texture baker" to output a version of the original pentastic1.tga texture, so in psp7 I could fade to black the inner edges where the decal sits on top of the rock`s cracks.

I`m especially pleased with how I got the decal`s mesh to follow the contours of those

post.author: Dewo
post.body: Hi Ratty, hi Kit! I'm here now .

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
for anyone interested in learning more about uv mapping and the lscm tool, here are two web page tutorials that I found helpful, the fist very basic, the 2nd advanced, but both have text and images.

The Basics of UV Mapping

Complex UV mapping tutorial

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: hi dewo, sorry I didn`t see your post before.

post.author: kat
post.body:
ratty redemption wrote:
...but I wonder how you would unwrap the "horns" or saber type "teeth" that are in the original hell maps and my version of them, like in this image....
Cylinder unwrap and place the seams on the outside of the model where they can't be easily seen by the player.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: thanks kat, although I`ve never used that before. and would it involve a seam going up say the back of the horn?

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
here is my first attempt at uv mapping using the method black dog suggested.



I`m pleased with how it looks in blender, but for some reason the vertex colors aren`t working on this model when loaded into blender.

in d3 the "r_showvertexcolor 1" shows a pure white model but in blender the vertex color has the top faces of the rock white fading to black for the sides and bottom of the rock.

could it be something to do with the seams that are preventing this from working?

edit: the pins are just to retain the size and rotation, but the distribution of uv`s is how the lscm unwrapped the model with it`s new seams.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
I got the vertex colors working again, it was my fault using my uv test material when exporting from blender which doesn`t have the "vcol paint" option enabled.

*ratty bangs head on desk*

but my normal d3 materials do and all seems to be working

post.author: kit89
post.body:
Yo Dewo.

Looking good Ratty, your getting the hang of this. For the horns, you could place a seam up the back of the horns. And if all the horns skin look the same, just place them on top of each other to reduce the texture size and your horns will look identical to each other.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
thanks kit89, and I`ve got a little more tweaking to the new rock I`ve been working on today but should have it finished tomorrow.

understood about the horns and yes they are all sharing the same uv map.

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
Oops, should have kept an eye on this thread.

Quote:
I`m not familiar with "merge to target vertex" is it different from "merge verts to cursor" available in older versions of blender?


Yes. Before 2.42 this kind of merging was still possible by placing the cursor near a selected vertex, snapping the cursor to the selection, making a new selection and then merging that to the cursor. That was a big pain in the ass. Now there's "merge to first" and "merge to last" in the merge menu, which perform this function nicely. This is particularly useful for optimising low poly work.

Quote:
regarding the (edge cutting) knife tool, I always snap the resulting cuts manually to grid using the "shift+s" popup menu, but I first have to either zoom in the 3d window to a small enough grid, or keep another 3d window on screen with a small grid size, so the snapped verts are fine enough, other wise the model comes out looking to blocky. is this similar to how you use the knife tool?


Yes, I do roughly the same thing. The problem with this comes when you wish to make a clean, grid aligned slice through an object with off-grid vertices. Curves are a good example. When slicing those I always end up shuffling the new vertexes around to get them aligned, and that's not an effective way to work. Blender is entirely capable of making a clean grid-aligned cut, there's just no tool to do it at the moment.

I sometimes resort to booleans, but they are pretty bad. The modifier stack and the recent improvements do make them more useable, but the fact that meshes must be closed and need cleaning up afterwards just kills the ease of use.

So I'd like a knife tool that snaps to the grid.

Quote:
I`m pleased with how it looks in blender, but for some reason the vertex colors aren`t working on this model when loaded into blender.


The easiest way to verify that your vertex colours have exported is to load up the .ase file in a text editor and search for MESH_VERTCOL. Vertex colours are indexed in the .ase format in lines that look like this:

*MESH_VERTCOL 0 1.0000 1.0000 1.0000

If you are missing those, the exporter hasn't included vertex colours.

Quote:
here is my first attempt at uv mapping using the method black dog suggested.


Looks like you've got the idea. The crack running underneath looks like it'll hide seams very well. I would be a touch wary of adding features like that for the sole reason of hiding seams, as you want your model to be shaped naturally and believably as well as appearing seamless - but from that shot, it looks ok.

Quote:
but I wonder how you would unwrap the "horns" or saber type "teeth" that are in the original hell maps and my version of them, like in this image.


As kit said, I'd unwrap those with a single seam running up the back. I agree that having all three horns share the same uvspace is a good idea. It means you can save work by only modelling and unwrapping one and copying that geometry (perhaps with small changes), and it gives you the option to paint features into the texture such as highlighting the tip, or pushing the colour at the base further towards that of the material the horn will be growing from. You could go even further and try and paint out the seams, but depending on how the horn is used it may not be worth that effort.
